body:
Can't reproduce unfortunately, on my machines matplotlib installs just fine.
Try not downgrading python and using a virtual environment as suggested in getting started guide, never had problems with that. Let me know if it solves your problem.
Well, I can try again but in principle, neither installation paths as described (pip or manual installation etc.) did work at first try.

I'm quoting directly from the getting started guide:
```
sudo apt install python3  # on ubuntu
brew install python3      # on mac

You may want to use a virtual environment to maintain an isolated Python environment.
In order to install Ludwig just run:

pip install ludwig

or install it by building the source code from the repository:

git clone git@github.com:uber/ludwig.git
cd ludwig
virtualenv -p python3 venv
source venv/bin/activate
pip install -r requirements.txt
python setup.py install
```
We suggest to use a virtual environment, have you done so? Did you follow exactly those instructions?
I'm not asking you to redo what you have already done, I'm suggesting to follow the instructions given in the guide, without Anaconda and without any downgraded python as there's nothing in the documentations that suggests so and using a virtual environment with python3.

If following exactly those instructions does not lead you to a working environment then there could be something wrong with Ludwig's installation procedure, but most likely there's something wrong with your environment and setup.

Hey,
yes, of course I would start and have started with the getting started guide as it looks straight forward and inviting (despite that I found that examples such as *.csv's and *.yaml's are not provided as files, but part of documentation only? - separate question)

Python installation:

```
ludwig1@ubuntu:~/dev/git/ludwig/ludwig$ sudo apt install python3
[sudo] password for ludwig1: 
Reading package lists... Done
Building dependency tree       
Reading state information... Done
python3 is already the newest version (3.6.7-1~18.04).
0 upgraded, 0 newly installed, 0 to remove and 11 not upgraded.
```

```
ludwig1@ubuntu:~/dev$ pip install ludwig
Collecting ludwig
  Could not find a version that satisfies the requirement ludwig (from versions: )
No matching distribution found for ludwig

```

There was a related bug here, but that was about TF: https://github.com/uber/ludwig/issues/102

Then, running virtual env:

> Hey, the **(venv)** indicates the virtual environment doesn't it?

yes but if you don't show me that the venv you created is a python 3 venv by showing either how you created it or what version is the python inside it i can't be sure you are doing things correctly.

> OK, here is some good news.
> After installation using pip3 instead of pip (and it was successful compared to the other VM still stuck at matplotlib), I can reproduce this output:
> 
> ```
> ludwig1@ubuntu:~$ python3 -m ludwig.train -h
> ```
Now it looks again that you outside the virtual environment. If you are withing a virtual environment initialized with python3 as the interpreter you don't need to use the python3 command but just the python command. Also I don't know in which directory you are when you are running this, if you actually have it installed or if you are running it from source, from the directory you pulled.
As this is getting pretty messy, I suggest you to read some guide on virtual environments, for instance [this one](https://docs.python-guide.org/dev/virtualenvs/) that will probably clarify all your doubts. Also I'm closing this issue as it's likely not a Ludwig issue but an issue with your configuration. You can keep on writing here if you want and I'll keep trying to help.
